Preprocessor

　TJS2 can process conditional compilation expressions (corresponding to #if and #endif in C). These are processed before the script is actually interpreted, allowing you to conditionally include or exclude parts of the script from being interpreted.
　Unlike C preprocessor directives, the style of conditional compilation expressions is freeform and can be written anywhere. There is no requirement to write only one directive per line as with C directives.

@set Directive

　The @set directive evaluates a conditional compilation expression and discards the result. The syntax is as follows:
    @set(expression)
　Write a conditional compilation expression in "expression". The following operators can be used here:

    ,  =  !=  ==  ||  &&  |  ^  &  <  >  <=  >=  +  -  %  *  /  !  +  -  ( )
　For the meaning of these operators, please see Expressions and Operators. However, the only data type that can be handled is integer.
　Additionally, you can use any variable or immediate value. For variable naming conventions, the same rules as those for variable naming and immediate values in Tokens apply.
　However, variables used in the preprocessor and variables used in the TJS2 script do not interfere with each other (they do not share the same namespace).

@if Directive, @endif Directive

　The @if directive evaluates a conditional compilation expression, and if the result is 0, it prevents the subsequent part until the next @endif from being interpreted. If the result is non-zero, it is interpreted.
　The syntax is as follows:

    @if(expression)              ...         @endif
    Specify a conditional compilation expression in "expression". @if ... @endif can be nested.


Example:
    @if(flag==0)  // A variable that has not had anything assigned yet is considered to be 0
        @set(flag=1)
        ****
    @endif
    // ↑ Makes the compilation of the script written in the **** part happen only once

    @if(version>=0x02040009)
        @if(flag)
            ****
        @endif
    @endif 
    // ↑ Compiles the **** part only when version is 0x02040009 (2.4.9) or higher and flag is non-zero

Predefined Variables

　The version variable represents the current version of TJS2.

　As a numerical value, it is in the format 0x0XYYZZZZ in hexadecimal, where the X part is the major version, the YY part is the minor version, and ZZZZ is the release number. For example, 0x02040009 means the version is 2.4.9.
